Award.AwardTitle: Support for Junior Investigators at the Sun Valley Workshop on Skeletal Biology; Sun Valley, Idaho; August 2-5, 2015

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This award provides funding to support travel awards for junior investigators, including underrepresented minorities, to attend the Sun Valley Workshop: Musculoskeletal Biology in Sun Valley, Idaho, on August 2-5, 2015. The overall objective of the Workshop is to improve understanding across the many disciplines that study skeletal biology and the prevention/treatment of skeletal disease including the biological response of bone to mechanical loading. Another goal is to develop the interdisciplinary collaborations which are especially important for younger scientists.

In 2015 the overall theme of the Workshop is "New Mechanisms for Old Problems", honoring the long-term and founding chairman WSS Jee and the concepts initiated at Sun Valley Workshops. The award will have a major impact on the participation of young investigators and trainees at the Workshop ensure. The support also will help establish as permanent the Career Development seminar. The goal is for this professional development opportunity to become a signature component of the workshop.

POR.DRECONTENT:
ORS Sun Valley Workshop: Musculoskeletal Biology, 2015

 

The objective of the Sun Valley Workshop is to improve understanding across the many disciplines that study skeletal biology, to provide new perspectives that lead to prevention and/or treatment of skeletal diseases, and to develop interdisciplinary collaborations, especially for younger scientists and scientists new to the field. The workshop receives support from the NIH, NSF, ASBMR, AAA.

 

In 2015, it was the 45th Sun Valley Workshop and the 50th year since the first Workshop was held in 1965. These anniversaries coincided with the 90th birthday of the founder of the Workshops, Dr. Web S.S. Jee, who was a special guest. The theme in 2015 was “New Mechanisms for Old Problems.” 3 sessions re-visited new data and perspectives on ideas originated throughout the years at the Workshop: Coupling of Bone Resorption and Formation; Identification, Regulation and Importance of Cortical Porosity; and Osteocyte Perilacunar Remodeling; and 2 sessions covered novel topics: 3D Printing to Regenerate Musculoskeletal Tissue; and Nerves, Bone, Joint Pain and Skeletal Homeostasis. In addition, Dr. Gayle Lester, from NIAMS, gave a short presentation on the new NIH Biosketch format and Submission Policies.

 

30 posters were presented, including posters from the 14 winners of the Young Investigator Awards, and a separate oral session from the 9 winners of the ASBMR/Frost Award. We also offered a Career Development session geared toward junior investigators, organized by Drs. M. van der Meulen and G. Lester, focused on “Planning and Negotiating Career Transitions.” Topics included mentoring, resources, and personnel, and were discussed by a panel comprised of Drs. T. Bellido, H. Donahue, D. Ke, G. Lester and N. Sims. More than 30 people attended with 25% graduate students, 55% postdoctoral fellows, and 20% Assistant Professors.

 

24 awards for junior investigators were given; all investigators presented their work from the podium or in a poster setting. Awards included 10 Alice L. Jee Memorial Travel Awards; 9 ASBMR/Harold M. Frost Awards; 1 award for osteoarthritis research; 3 Under-represented Minority Travel Awards; and 1 young investigator award in honor of Dr. Charles Turner.

 

Continuing a tradition of mentorship, lunches between young investigators and more senior investigators were arranged for all Award winners. All invited speakers and several senior investigators who attended but were not speakers served as mentors. As an additional aspect of mentorship, we appointed a pre-workshop young investigator mentor, who worked prior to the Workshop with the young investigators on content and length of their presentations.  

 

We are committed to the active participation of women in these Workshops. Women have constituted about 32-37% of the participants. In 2015, 33% of the participants were women. 4 of 7 session chairs (57%), and 33% of the invited speakers (not including the award winners, or the Career session) were women. 5 of the 8 members of the Advisory Board are women.   

 

4% of the participants were under-represented minorities (1 African-American and 3 Hispanic). We will continue to support URMs with young investigator and travel awards.  We will contact labs personally to make them aware that there will be at least 5 fellowships available only to underrepresented minorities. 

 

These are some of the comments received for the 2015 meeting:

 

  1. This meeting is much better than a large meeting where there are many lectures but little discussion. This meeting promotes understanding the topics covered in a session. Since there is so much information and learning going on, it is helpful to have afternoons off to mull through what was learned in morning sessions and to regenerate for more learning in the evening session!
  2. It was one of the best meetings I have ever attended. The format (questions allowed and encouraged) made for a very lively, interesting and intellectually vibrant meeting.
  3. It is hard to value the various aspects that make this meeting unique. The excellent program together with the format and the unique location create what distinct Sun Valley from any other meetings. Without this combination, the meeting will lose its essence, other locations or other format will ruin a format successful for 45 years!!! Thank you for another great meeting!
  4. This is a very high value meeting both because of the excellent speakers and program content and because of the format. Please do not change this workshop, and please do not let it grow too large.
  5. This is the highlight meeting of the year as far as I’m concerned.
  6. The meeting format with free afternoons allowed for networking opportunities, which are vital for developing researchers. I was able to meet with Dr. Martin, Dr. Kneissel, and Dr. Andersen while also establishing connections with other post docs and graduate students. Poster/speaker sessions also facilitated discussion. Overall, this conference was incredible.  

 

Respectfully submitted,

 

Teresita Bellido, PhD

Co-Director, Sun Valley Workshop on Musculoskeletal Biology                   795 words, max 800 words
